G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper with the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, as Emily resides in Middlesex County and this Court issued the original custody order in this matter.

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Changes in parental distance and the needs of the child are recognized under Massachusetts family law as sufficient grounds for modification.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion rejects the idea that a custodial parent’s relocation, standing alone, is a sufficient ‘material and substantial change’ to justify modification of custody. It emphasizes that a modification must rest on a material and substantial change in circumstances ‘other than the move,’ and it does not state that evolving ‘needs of the child’ by themselves are sufficient grounds. Thus, the case does not support the broader proposition that changes in parental distance and child’s needs are recognized as sufficient grounds for modification under Massachusetts law.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The paramount consideration in custody and parenting time decisions is the best interest of the child.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly states that removal decisions under G.L. c. 208, § 30 turn on whether removal is in the children’s best interests and applies that standard to the custody/parenting-time modification sought. The court explains that in joint physical custody situations, “cause shown” means a showing that removal is in the “best interests” of the children, and then reviews the judge’s decision solely through that lens, confirming that the children’s best interests are the controlling consideration. Although focused on relocation, it clearly frames the governing standard in terms of the child’s best interests as paramount.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that … [a] minor child … shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders… ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a material change in circumstances is required to modify a prior custody order.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas concerns an initial divorce and custody judgment and the custodial parent’s request to remove the children to Greece. It analyzes standards for initial custody determinations and for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not the standard for modifying a prior custody order. The court never discusses a requirement of a material change in circumstances to modify an existing custody judgment, so it does not support the proposition stated.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change …”

*Malone v. Malone*, 84 Mass. App. Ct. 11.proposition: In *Malone v. Malone*, 84 Mass. App. Ct. 1116 (2013), the Court emphasized the importance of minimizing disruption to a child’s routine and stability when crafting a parenting schedule.

*Chancellor v. Chancellor*, 23 Mass. App.proposition: Other authorities, including *Chancellor v. Chancellor*, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 1005 (1987) and *Heller v. Heller*, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 924 (1992), reaffirm that the rationale for crafting fair and reasonable custody arrangements may need to be revisited when circumstances materially change.
*Chancellor v. Chancellor*, 23 Mass. App.case_name: School Committee of Norton v. Norton Teachers' Ass'n
*Chancellor v. Chancellor*, 23 Mass. App.support_reasoning: This opinion is not Chancellor v. Chancellor and does not concern child custody or modification of custody arrangements. It addresses the scope of an arbitrator’s authority in a public‑sector labor dispute involving a teacher’s termination and evaluation procedures. Nothing in the reasoning discusses family law, changed circumstances, or revisiting custody determinations, so it cannot support the claimed proposition about custody arrangements needing reconsideration when circumstances materially change.
*Chancellor v. Chancellor*, 23 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: “The committee’s stronger argument may be that reinstatement is a remedy which exceeds the arbitrator’s authority because it negates a decision which the arbitrator admittedly cannot examine directly. While the argument has surface appeal, the question was settled adversely to the committee’s position by the Supreme Judicial Court’s decision in School Comm. of West Bridge-water v. West Bridgewater Teacher’s Assn., 372 Mass. 121 (1977).”

*Heller v. Heller*, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 92.proposition: Other authorities, including *Chancellor v. Chancellor*, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 1005 (1987) and *Heller v. Heller*, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 924 (1992), reaffirm that the rationale for crafting fair and reasonable custody arrangements may need to be revisited when circumstances materially change.
*Heller v. Heller*, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 92.support_reasoning: The opinion in Heller v. Heller (Feathler v. Feathler) deals with initial division of marital property and alimony, including treatment of a pension and the award of the marital home, but it does not address modification of custody or the need to revisit custody arrangements upon materially changed circumstances. Custody is mentioned only tangentially (as a factor in property division) and there is no discussion of subsequent changes in circumstances or revisiting prior custody rationales. Thus it does not support the stated proposition about revisiting custody arrangements when circumstances materially change.
*Heller v. Heller*, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 92.relevant_excerpt: “In this situation, the judge elected to treat the assets separately and ordered the house transferred to the wife. He also rightly considered that, as a custodial parent, the wife needed the marital home as a domicil for their son. King v. King, 373 Mass. 37, 38 (1977).”
